newsitem.title: USA: US Southeast power continues to falter on weather.
newsitem.headline: US Southeast power continues to falter on weather.

text.p: Spot bulk electricity prices in the U.S. Southeast continued to soften Monday in light trade, pressured by a return of milder temperatures and the absence of traders due to the Martin Luther King, Jr. holiday.
Temperatures in the Southeast are expected to hover near or slightly above-normal Tuesday but then climb to about five to 15 degrees Fahrenheit above normal by Wednesday.
Colder air is forecast for the weekend.
Firm, peak power prices into the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) territory for Tuesday tumbled into the $12.00-13.00 per megawatt hour (MWh) range, as compared with the $19.00-21.00 range on Friday.

Firm, off-peak power into TVA was offered at $14.00 and $14.50, but no deals could be confirmed done at those levels. Traders notionally assessed the market at $10.00-11.00. This is compared with Friday's $12.50-14.00 trading range.
At the Georgia/Florida border, firm, peak electricity prices in 16 hour blocks for Tuesday delivery were softer at $20.50-21.75 from $21.50-23.50 on Friday.
Firm, off-peak power for Tuesday at the Ga./Fla. border fell to $14.00-15.00, down about a $1 from Friday.
In Florida, firm, peak prices for 16-hour blocks of electricity were talked in the $22.00-23.00 per MWh range.
As in the power market, natural gas prices along the Gulf Coast pipes fell by about 60 cents to the $3.20s, as buyers in the East relied on ample storage supplies.
